column17: Unlike the other profiles and resources beling balloted, None of the C-CDA profiles (header, Care Plan, CCD, etc.) have element definitions (e.g. you cannot click on the element to get a definition of the element).

column15:
Extension Extension: Sex of patient assigned at birth - Mappings

Mappings for HL7 v2 Mapping (http://hl7.org/v2) - Mapped to HL7 Version 2 PID-8 

Mappings for RIM Mapping (http://hl7.org/v3) to "administrativeGender"
column16:
V2 - to OBX-5 Observation Value.

V3 - Map to "ObservationValue      [2.16.840.1.113883.5.1063]"
column17:
PID-8 is "Administrative Sex" which is not the same as birth sex.  "Administrative Sex" is used for administrative purposes such as inpatient bed assignment and billing/claims processing.  

Accurate Birth sex is critical for laboratory result reporting and in V2  and V3 should be reported as a clinical observation.  PID-8 was originally (up until V2.4) titled "Sex" but the field  title was clarified for harmonization when HL7 Version 3 differentiated the concepts of "administrative gender" defined as "The gender of a person used for administrative purposes (as opposed to clinical gender)" thus creating two distinct concepts.   

Suggest working with Patient Administration to determine whether it is possible to clarify the definition of V2 PID-8 to include Birth Sex, but since V2 is normative and per ANSI, has to be backward compatible this may not be possible.  

Another alternative is to add a new field to the V2 PID segment to capture Birth Sex.

Consistent with FHIR STU-3 Implementer's Safety Checklist #9 (http://hl7.org/fhir/2016Sep/safety.html), please make AuditEvent and Provenance mandatory for resource creation or update events.  In this case, at creation/update of the resource instances that correspond to (or are a subset of) a CCDA instance.
How are provenance metadata for CCDA sections and elements represented in FHIR?  Provenance includes at least:  WHO with role and participation, WHEN, WHERE and WHY.
column18: How are provenance metadata for CCDA sections and elements represented in FHIR?

column17: The CLD states the value set is contain a list of LOINC class codes that are all "LOINC Part" codes. LP codes are not a formal part of the LOINC code system and can not be used as exchangable codes. It is permissable (I think) to use them in a CLD  when they are used to identify different actual LOINC codes, but not when they are the codes that are to be included in the value set expansion. Given the expecation that this value set have "types", either you need to find a different code system, ask LOINC to change the policy, or remove this attribute. This being an example value set does not mean the value set that breaks LOINC rules can be allowed.

Would it be better to associate this with a role and have the role be how the attribution is characterized - As "self", Mother, Legal gardian, etc?

column17: link does not work

Current ballot content
The implementation guide is presented as profiles on the Composition resource. I don’t think this does justice to the strengths of both standards - CDA and FHIR. Instead of attempting to recreate a C-CDA document as a set of compositions, the implementation guide would be much more useful addressing two actual use cases: 
? when a C-CDA needs to be generated based on existing, possibly distributed data available in the form of FHIR resources
? when data from existing C-CDA content needs to be presented to consumer of FHIR resources
Proposed ballot content
As the ballot already mentions, some of the work of representing C-CDA information as FHIR resources is already done as part of the DAF profiles. This implementation guide should illustrate the above-mentioned use cases with this existing content, and develop anything missing. The focus should be on the amount of data from using “vanilla” FHIR resources that can be represented or used for building a C-CDA document, and highlight any extensions necessary. This will also allow for the identifications of any gaps regarding the implementation of each of the base standards, FHIR and C-CDA.

column15: OID: 2.16.840.1.113883.4.642.2.languages (for OID based terminology systems)
column17:
The proposed OID is defined as the RFC5646 language tags. There is no OID for the ever-changing BCP47. This replaces 2.16.840.1.113883.6.121. No idea what the oid given by FHIR means.
The definition at HL7 OID reg: The code system used to uniquely identify a language as described in the RFC5646 (http://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5646.txt) as defined in the "current" specification of BCP47 (http://tools.ietf.org/html/bcp47). The elements needed for the code system are provided by the IANA Language Subtag Registry (http://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry) Usage of the code system is best explained by http://www.w3.org/International/articles/language-tags/Overview.en.php and http://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-choosing-language-tags. The CLDR - Unicode Common Locale Data Repository project is a source for application libraries to support implementing this code system.

column15: Composition.language Common Languages binding : extensible Common Languages
column17: While I can see that some argue that a new language not in the RFC would present a problem but sending a made up language code is not reasonable. This should be required binding
